The patient has had 2 sexual relationships in the past 3 years and has been sexually active with her current boyfriend for the past 6 months. Her temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min. Skin examination is shown below. The remainder of her physical examination is within normal limits:

There is no associated pruritus, pain, or other symptoms. His medical history is unremarkable, and he has no history of tobacco or alcohol use. Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin examination shows a firm, mobile nodule, as shown in the image below. There is no drainage from the lesion or tenderness to palpation. The lesion does not change shape when pinched at the edges. The remainder of the physical examination is within normal limits.

questions.text: What will be the 95% confidence interval (CI) for an estimated prevalence of 10% and a sample size of 100?
Identify the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endemic typhus

 

  • The image shows a flea (reddish-brown, wingless insect with laterally compressed body).
  • Fleas are the vectors of several zoonotic diseases.
  • Specifically, Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) transmits Rickettsia typhi → causes Endemic (Murine) Typhus.
  • Reservoir: rodents (rats).
  • Transmission: flea bite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidemic typhus:

 

  • Caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.
  • Vector = human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis), not fleas.

 

Option C. Q fever:

 

  • Caused by Coxiella burnetii.
  • No arthropod vector; transmitted via inhalation of aerosols from infected animals (placenta, urine, feces).

 

Option D. Scrub typhus:

 

  • Caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.
  • Vector = trombiculid mite (chigger mite), not fleas.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician complaining of worsening acne. He has scattered papules and pustules with mild-to-moderate redness at the forehead, nose, and chin. His acne has been present for 2 years. The lesions are not painful, but the boy is concerned as the symptoms have progressively worsened and his peers at school are starting to make fun of him. He currently uses topical tretinoin and washes his face twice daily with benzoyI peroxide. His medical history is otherwise negative. On examination, he has moderate pustular acne with erythema but no scarring. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to fever and facial rash for 2 days. The patient has a history of atopic dermatitis for which his parents occasionally apply over-the-counter steroid cream. The boy had a flare-up of dry, thickened, itchy skin on his cheeks 4 days ago. He then developed many overlying, painful bumps 2 days ago that have since increased in number. His vaccinations are up to date. Physical examination shows an uncomfortable-appearing child with numerous painful, clear vesicles over erythematous skin on both cheeks as well as a few scattered lesions with overlying dark-red crusting. Submandibular lymphadenopathy is present. The rest of the skin appears dry. The initial gram stain of one of the lesions is negative. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's rash?

choices.text: Administer top up NM blocking agent
Ask surgeon to limit blood loss

questions.text: You are a very smart intern and the anaesthetist on duty trusts you with monitoring a patient after induction while he goes to the next case and asks you to give any medications if needed. You keep observing the monitor continuously and is shown in the image below. What is the next step in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer top up NM bloking agent

 

The image shows multiple Troughs in the yellow waveform, i.e.,. Curare clefts on the capnography, which indicate partial return of spontaneous respiratory efforts during mechanical ventilation.

 

This occurs when the effect of the neuromuscular blocking (NMB) agent is wearing off.

 

The appropriate response is to administer a top-up dose of NMB agent to maintain adequate muscle relaxation for surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV dantrolene sodium: Used to treat malignant hyperthermia, which presents with rapid rise in ETCO₂, hyperthermia, tachycardia, rigidity. Malignant hyperthermia shows stepladder pattern of sudden rise in ETCO2 as shown:         

 

 

Option C. Reassure yourself that “all is well”: Ignoring curare clefts could lead to inadequate muscle relaxation, patient movement, or interference with surgery.

 

Option D. Ask surgeon to limit blood loss: Not relevant to curare clefts; blood loss does not cause this capnography pattern. On capnography, this typically shows as gradual decrease in end-tidal CO₂ (ETCO2), because CO₂ delivery to the lungs falls due to reduced cardiac output.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about health indicators:

  1. Number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on current rates of sickness and mortality-Sullivan index
  2. Simplest measure of burden of disease-Incidence
  3. Optimal utilisation of health services-Negative Bed turnover ratio
  4. Best indicator of effectiveness of health care-IMR
  5. Cost effectiveness of NHP-DALY
  6. Best measure of standard of living-HDI
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4, 6

 

  • IMR is the best indicator of effectiveness of health care services.
  • HDI is considered the best measure of standard of living.
  • Other options explained:
  • Sullivan index → Only Disability free LE 
  • Incidence as simplest burden measure → Proportional Mortality rate is considered as simplest measure of burden.
  • Negative bed turnover ratio for utilization →  It should be slightly positive 
  • DALY for NHP cost-effectiveness → QALY is used as measure

questions.text: 56-year-old woman comes to the office due to a 1-year history of skin lesions. He has had rough, flaky spots, which do not itch or bleed, on his forehead and cheeks. The patient has attempted treatment with various emollients without effect. Medical history includes hypertension. The patient works as a building inspector and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are normal. On examination multiple scattered white, scaling lesions are noted, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

You are filling the death certificate of a patient who died from ventricular fibrillation following an acute myocardial infarction. This was because of thrombosis in the coronary artery due to longstanding atherosclerosis. What will you record in line I (c) of the death certificate?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Coronary artery thrombosis

questions.text:
Match the following with the images:

 

 

  1. Lichen simplex chronicus

  2. Lichen scrofulosorum

  3. Lichen planus

  4. Lichen sclerosus

  5. Lichen nitidus
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-A, 2-D, 3-B, 4-C

 

1 - Lichen Simplex Chronicus (A): Lichen simplex chronicus results from chronic scratching or rubbing causing thick, leathery, hyperpigmented plaques with exaggerated skin markings. It is common on accessible sites like the ankle, wrist, or neck. Itching often triggers a vicious scratch-itch cycle worsened by stress or underlying skin conditions.

 

2 - Lichen Sclerosus (D): Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory disorder presenting as pale, atrophic, sclerotic plaques mainly involving the anogenital region. It leads to thinning, wrinkling, and sometimes scarring or architectural distortion of vulvar skin. Symptoms include intense pruritus and soreness, especially in women.

 

3 - Lichen Scrofulosorum (B): Lichen scrofulosorum is a tuberculid characterized by multiple grouped perifollicular papules mostly on trunk and limbs. It occurs as a hypersensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis elsewhere in the body, typically in young individuals. Lesions are asymptomatic or mildly pruritic and indicate latent or active TB.

 

4 - Lichen Planus (C): Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disorder presenting as violaceous, flat-topped, polygonal papules with fine white lines (Wickham striae). It mainly affects wrists, ankles, and mucous membranes. Pruritus is common and lesions may heal with post-inflammatory pigmentation; it involves an immune-mediated reaction often triggered by drugs or infections.

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis for a young male depicted in the image is?
A new drug has been introduced into the market which was found to decrease mortality but it does not cure the disease. Which of the following is a true statement regarding prevalence and incidence?
A study found that the incidence of bladder carcinoma is 5 times higher in smokers than in non smokers. Calculate the attributable risk:

Match the following congenital lesions with the genetic defects:

 

 

A- NEMO

B-GNAQ

C- Collagen VII

D- Transglutaminase 1
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1- C. Collagen VII: This gene defect causes dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, characterized by skin fragility and blister formation following minor trauma. The mutation affects anchoring fibrils in the dermo-epidermal junction. Clinically, it presents as congenital blistering and scarring primarily on hands, feet, and other trauma-prone areas.

 

2-D. Transglutaminase 1: Mutation in transglutaminase 1 causes lamellar ichthyosis, leading to thick, plate-like scaling and collodion membrane at birth. This enzyme is crucial for cross-linking proteins in the skin barrier. The child’s skin is dry, scaly, and prone to cracking due to impaired cornified envelope formation.

 

3-B. GNAQ: GNAQ mutations cause vascular malformations such as port-wine stains seen in Sturge-Weber syndrome. This gene encodes a G protein involved in signal transduction in endothelial cells. Patients present with cutaneous capillary malformations often associated with neurological and ocular abnormalities.

 

4-A. NEMO: NEMO gene mutations cause incontinentia pigmenti, an X-linked dominant disorder affecting skin, teeth, and the nervous system. The skin lesions progress through blistering, wart-like, hyperpigmented, and hypopigmented stages following Blaschko’s lines. It involves defective NF-kappaB pathway regulation critical for cell survival and immune response.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with no known medical conditions undergoes elective surgery under general anesthesia. During the procedure, the anesthesia team observes rapidly increasing body temperature, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, and generalized muscle rigidity. Identify the correct kit for the clinical presentations:

 

  1. Painful ulcers upon palpation, with suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy on the right side
  2. Vaginal discharge in a CSW with cervical erosions 
  3. Painful, swollen, and tender inguinal lymph node in a truck driver
  4. Painless ulcer in the genital area with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy in CSW; past h/o treatment of a similar lesion resulted in fever, malaise, tachycardia and vomiting
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-White, 2-Grey, 3-Black, 4-White


Syndromic management kits are color-coded in India for STDs/RTIs. 

 

  • Painful ulcers with suppurative lymphadenopathy suggest chancroid (treated with White kit). 
  • Vaginal discharge with cervical erosions in CSW suggests bacterial vaginosis/trichomoniasis (treated with Grey kit). 
  • Painful, swollen inguinal lymph nodes in truck driver point toward lymphogranuloma venereum (treated with Black kit).
  • Painless ulcer with systemic Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction on treatment indicates syphilis (treated with White kit containing benzathine penicillin).

 

STI KITS:

choices.text: CV of DBP is more than Vitamin D
CV of Vitamin D is more than DBP
Both DBP and Vitamin D have equal variability
It cannot be ascertained from information provided

questions.text: A study was conducted on two different samples for comparing variation between DBP and Vitamin D. The mean diastolic blood pressure is 110 mm Hg with standard deviation 11 and the mean vitamin D level is 18 with standard deviation 3. Which of the following statement is true regarding the coefficient of variation (CV)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CV of Vitamin D is more than DBP

 

 

  • CV of DBP = 11/110 ×100 = 10%. 
  • CV of Vitamin D = 3/18 ×100 = 16.7%. 

 

Hence, Vitamin D shows greater relative variability than DBP.

questions.text:
Match the histological images with the correct diagnosis:

 

 

  1. Pemphigus

  2. Hailey hailey

  3. Psoriasis

  4. Lichen planus

  5. Melanoma

  6. BCC

  7. Mycoises fungoides
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-A, 2-C, 3-D, 4-F

 

1-A: Pemphigus Vulgaris: Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized histologically by a suprabasal split in the epidermis. This means that the separation occurs just above the basal cell layer, leaving the basal cells attached to the basement membrane like a "row of tombstones." 

 

2-C: Psoriasis: Key findings: Uniform elongation of rete ridges, regular acanthosis, thinning of suprapapillary plates, and parakeratosis. Munro microabscesses (neutrophils in the stratum corneum) may be present, along with a chronic inflammatory background typical for psoriasis.

 

3-D: Lichen planus: Characterized by a dense, band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction, "saw-tooth" appearance of rete ridges, and hypergranulosis. Basal cell degeneration and Civatte bodies may also be seen in lichen planus. 

 

4-F: Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC):

  • This histopathological image shows nests of basaloid cells, a classic feature of Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC). 
  • In BCC, the tumor islands often display peripheral palisading, where cells at the edges align in a parallel fashion, resembling a picket fence.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements about LA

1. Maximum methHb-Procaine

2. Most cardiotoxic- Bupivacaine

3. LA of choice in MH-Prilocaine

4. LA with vasoconstriction-Cocaine

Match the following images in the extremities with the diagnosis:

 

 

A-Diabetes

B-Graves disease

C-Lofgren syndrome

D-Varicose veins

E-Hypothyroidism

F-IBD
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-F

 

1-A: Diabetes (Diabetic ulcer): The first image shows a chronic, punched-out ulcer with an erythematous base and surrounding callus, typical of a diabetic ulcer. Diabetic ulcers occur due to neuropathy and vascular insufficiency, commonly on lower extremities. These ulcers are slow-healing and prone to infection, often seen in patients with poorly controlled diabetes.

 

2-B: Graves disease (Pretibial myxedema): The second image shows bilateral, rubbery, non-pitting, waxy plaques on the shins, typical of pretibial myxedema. Associated with Graves disease, it is due to mucopolysaccharide deposition in the dermis. Lesions are usually non-tender, indurated, and may be skin-colored or erythematous.

 

3-C: Lofgren syndrome (Erythema nodosum): The third image demonstrates multiple, bright red, symmetric, tender nodules over the shins. This is classic for erythema nodosum, a hallmark of acute sarcoidosis in Lofgren syndrome. Lofgren syndrome also  features bilateral  hilar lymphadenopathy and arthritis.

 

4-F: IBD (Pyoderma gangrenosum): The fourth image shows a large, painful, necrotic ulcer with undermined violaceous edges. Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rapidly progressive ulcerative cutaneous condition seen in association with IBD. Lesions are extremely  painful, can  enlarge quickly, and heal with cribriform scarring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option D. Varicose veins: Leads to venous ulcers, typically around the medial malleolus, with irregular, shallow bases.

 

Option E. Hypothyroidism: Causes myxedema with generalized swelling, rarely produces specific localized leg lesions.

questions.text: You are planning to administer spinal anesthesia to a young female. Which of the following needles would be the most suitable for reducing the risk of a post-dural puncture headache?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25G Whitacre

 

  • Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) is caused by CSF leak through the dural puncture site.
  • Needle characteristics that reduce PDPH:
    • Smaller gauge → less tissue trauma → smaller dural hole → less CSF leak.
    • Pencil-point (non-cutting) tip → separates rather than cuts dural fibers, promoting faster closure.
  • 25G Whitacre is a small, pencil-point needle, which minimizes PDPH risk compared to cutting needles (Quincke) or larger gauges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 22G Quincke: Larger cutting needle → higher PDPH risk.

 

Option B. 22G Whitacre: Pencil-point, but larger gauge → moderate PDPH risk.

 

Option C. 25G Quincke: Small gauge reduces risk, but the cutting tip still increases PDPH chance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For young adults, especially females, use small-gauge pencil-point needles, so as to reduce the chance of PDPH.

questions.text:

Identify the correct statements:

  1. Direct observation with a structured checklist is the best method to survey the injection practices of health workers.
  2. Mass drug administration done for Worm infestation, Vitamin A deficiency and Scabies.
  3. Innermost circle of Rule of haves denotes hypertensives getting treatment.

Identify the correct statements about vaccines

  1. Influenza and yellow fever vaccines are CI in egg allergy

  2. Abscess formation post-BCG is treated conservatively

  3. Live vaccines should not be given with Human immunoglobulin except measles

  4. All of the following are killed vaccines: Pertussis, Salk, SA14-14-2, 17D

  5. NS is used as diluent for Danish 1331
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,5

 

1. Influenza and yellow fever vaccines are CI in egg allergy: Correct. Both are prepared in egg medium; severe egg allergy is a contraindication.

 

2. Abscess formation post-BCG is treated conservatively: Incorrect. Cold abscess after BCG is aspirated, not left alone.

 

3. Live vaccines should not be given with Human immunoglobulin except measles: Incorrect. Exception is tetanus and Hep B

 

4. All of the following are killed vaccines: Pertussis, Salk, SA14-14-2, 17D → Incorrect.

 

  • Pertussis (killed, whole cell) 
  • Salk (inactivated polio) 
  • SA14-14-2 (Japanese encephalitis live attenuated) 
  • 17D (Yellow fever live attenuated) 

 

5. NS is used as diluent for Danish 1331 (BCG strain): Correct. So, the correct statements = 1 and 5 only.

questions.text: Identify the type of study described in the scenario:

Identify the correct statements about lower extent of the following structures:

  1. Subarachnoid space-Lower border of S2
  2. Filum terminale-Coccyx
  3. Spinal cords in infants-Lower border of L3
  4. Adult spinal cord-Lower border of L1
A 35-year-old woman presents to a PHC with skin lesions with sensory loss. On examination, the dermatologist observes the following morphology. How would you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)

 

 

The skin lesions with sensory loss in this patient are characteristic of leprosy. The treatment involves multidrug therapy (MDT) using the blister pack shown in option (a). This MDT pack generally contains rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine, which are standard first-line drugs recommended by WHO for leprosy. Early use of MDT halts disease progression, prevents disability, and reduces transmission. 

 

Dosage:

 

  • Rifampicin 600 mg (once monthly, supervised)
  • Clofazimine 300 mg (once monthly, supervised) + 50 mg daily (unsupervised)
  • Dapsone 100 mg daily (unsupervised)
  • The duration is for 12 months for MB leprosy  in adults

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. The image shows the standard WHO MDT (Multi-Drug Therapy) blister pack for paucibacillary leprosy. This blue pack is used to treat patients diagnosed with paucibacillary (PB) leprosy, where there are fewer skin lesions[<5] and no nerve involvement.

 

Dosage:

 

  • Rifampicin: 600 mg once monthly (supervised dose); 
  • Dapsone: 100 mg daily (unsupervised dose); 
  • Duration: 6 months (6 monthly blister packs) for PB leprosy in adults

 

Option C. This is the green WHO MDT (Multi-Drug Therapy) blister pack for paucibacillary (PB) leprosy, specifically formulated for children

 

Dosage:

 

  • Rifampicin:
    •  450 mg for children 10-14 years,
    •  300 mg for children under 10
    • Dapsone:
    •  50 mg daily for children 10-14 years, 
    •  25 mg for under 10 years. Alternate day dosing (50 mg) can be used for young children.
    • The duration is for 6 months for PB leprosy in Children

 

Option D. This is the Brown WHO MDT (Multi-Drug Therapy) blister pack for Multibacillary (MB) leprosy, specifically formulated for children

 

The WHO MDT (Multi-Drug Therapy) dose for multibacillary (MB) leprosy in children is generally weight-based and adjusted as follows:

 

  • Rifampicin:
    • Children 10-14 years: 450 mg once monthly (supervised),
    • Children under 10 years: 300 mg once monthly
  • Clofazimine:
    •  Children 10-14 years: 150 mg once monthly plus 50 mg daily (alternate day dosing for younger children), 
    • Children under 10 years: 100 mg once monthly plus 50 mg daily (usually alternate day)
  • Dapsone:
    • Children 10-14 years: 50 mg daily.
    • Children under 10 years: 25 mg daily or 50 mg on alternate days

 

The duration of treatment is 12 months for MB leprosy in children

questions.text: What is the appropriate size for ET tube for child aged 8?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6mm

 

ET tube size in children can be estimated using the age-based formula (uncuffed tube):

 

  • Internal diameter (mm)=[4/Age in years]​+4

 

Here, for a 8yr child, 8/4+4=6mm

 

  • This size ensures adequate ventilation while minimizing the risk of airway trauma.
  • Cuffed tubes may require 0.5 mm smaller size compared to uncuffed tubes.

questions.text: You are a healthcare provider working in a community clinic. A 29-year-old male patient presents to your clinic with complaints of persistent fatigue, unexplained weight loss of approximately 10kg over the past three months, and recurrent episodes of night sweats. He admits to engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners and sharing needles for intravenous drug use in the past. He has a history of a RTA 1year back for which he received iv fluids and blood transfusion. On physical examination, you observe generalized lymphadenopathy and a rash on his trunk. Which of the following is the most efficient route of transmission of the likely infection in this case?

choices.text: Giant cells in a Tzanck preparation
Invasive cords of squamous cells with keratin pearls
Invasive clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisaded basal cells

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the office due to a slightly painful sore on his lip which has been enlarging for the last 3months. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. He works as a farmer and has no new sexual contacts. Vital signs are normal. Examination shows a 3x7-mm partially encrusted ulcer in the vermilion zone of the lower lip, surrounded by a 6x12-mm area of induration. There are no palpable submental or submandibular lymph nodes, and the remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Biopsy of this lesion will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Invasive cords of squamous cells with keratin pearls

 

The chronic, enlarging, ulcerated lesion with induration on the lower lip is highly suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lip, a malignancy commonly seen with chronic sun exposure. Farmers are particularly at risk. SCC of the lip typically appears as a nonhealing ulcer or crusted plaque, often indurated and sometimes tender.

 

Biopsy in SCC will show:

 

  • Invasive cords or nests of atypical squamous cells
  • Presence of keratin pearls (round collections of keratinized cells within tumor nests)
    This appearance is pathognomonic for well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giant cells in a Tzanck preparation: Giant cells observed in a Tzanck smear are multinucleated keratinocytes commonly seen in viral infections such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV). These giant cells arise due to virus-induced cytopathic effects causing cell fusion. This finding is diagnostic for herpes infections .

 

Option B. Granulomatous inflammation: Granulomatous inflammation is a distinct pattern of chronic inflammation characterized by the aggregation of macrophages transformed into epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells. It is typically seen in infectious diseases like tuberculosis, deep fungal infections, and certain autoimmune conditions such as sarcoidosis.

 

Option D. Invasive clusters of spindle cells surrounded by palisaded basal cells: This histopathological pattern is characteristic of basal cell carcinoma (BCC), a common skin cancer arising from basal keratinocytes. BCC shows nests of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading nuclei and stromal retraction. It generally presents as pearly papules, commonly seen over face.

choices.text: The asymmetrical funnel plot suggests that the studies with smaller sample sizes tend to report larger effect sizes, indicating potential bias.
An asymmetrical funnel plot is an expected result when conducting a meta-analysis and does not require further investigation.
The funnel plot's asymmetry is indicative of the heterogeneity of study designs and does not reflect publication bias.
The asymmetrical funnel plot is a result of errors in data collection and analysis, and the meta-analysis should be repeated with corrected data.

questions.text: You are conducting a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess the publication bias in studies investigating the efficacy of a new drug for a rare medical condition. As part of your analysis, you decide to create a funnel plot to visualize potential publication bias. You gather data from 20 relevant studies and calculate effect sizes for each study. After plotting these effect sizes against their corresponding standard errors, you notice that the funnel plot appears asymmetrical, with a gap on one side. What is the most appropriate interpretation of the asymmetrical funnel plot in this context?
questions.solution: Ans. A. The asymmetrical funnel plot suggests that the studies with smaller sample sizes tend to report larger effect sizes, indicating potential bias.

questions.text: Match the following scale types with their lesions?

A 42-year-old mancomes to the office due to an itchy rash. The rash began 3 months ago during the summer since then has enlarged and spread across his back, chest, and abdomen. The patient has attempted treatment with topical emollients and over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream without relief. Examination reveals scaly, annular plaques, as shown in the exhibit. In addition to appropriate measures for treatment of the rash, which of the following should be done at this time?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV screening test

 

The patient’s presentation of widespread scaly, annular plaques that are persistent and resistant to topical therapies is most consistent with tinea corporis (dermatophytosis). Extensive dermatophytosis, especially when chronic and involving large areas of the body, should raise concern for underlying immunosuppression. HIV infection is a major risk factor for extensive, recurrent, or atypical fungal infections due to impaired cell-mediated immunity. Therefore, in addition to antifungal therapy, it is essential to perform HIV screening at this time. This helps identify an underlying cause of his susceptibility and allows timely initiation of appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antinuclear antibody assay: This test is used for diagnosing autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus or mixed connective tissue disease. These conditions may have skin manifestations, but they typically present with photosensitive rashes or systemic features, not annular, scaly plaques typical of dermatophytosis.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B serology: This is indicated in patients who are to receive systemic immunosuppressants such as methotrexate or biologics, since reactivation of hepatitis B can occur. However, it is not related to the evaluation of widespread tinea corporis and not indicated at this stage.

 

Option D. Rule out beta blocker usage: Beta blockers are associated with psoriasis exacerbation, not fungal infections. While psoriasis may present with plaques, they are usually sharply demarcated and silvery, not annular scaly lesions spreading in this fashion.

questions.text:
Which of the following is included in high-quality CPR?

  1. Compression depth of at least 5 cm

  2. Rotate chest compressor every 3 mins

  3. Avoid excessive ventilation

  4. Compression - ventilation ratio of 30:2

  5. Allow complete recoil

  6. ET co2 <10mm

  7. Intra-arterial DBP >20mm Hg

  8. Breaths 20-30/min
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, 5, 7

 

High-quality CPR requires:

 

1. Compression depth of at least 5 cm: Ensures adequate cardiac output.

 

3. Avoid excessive ventilation: prevents increased intrathoracic pressure, which can reduce venous return.

 

4. Compression-ventilation ratio of 30:2: standard for adult CPR in a single rescuer scenario.

 

5. Allow complete recoil: Allows the heart to refill between compressions.

 

7. Intra-arterial diastolic pressure >20 mmHg: indicates effective perfusion during compressions.

 

Incorrect Statements:

 

2. Rotate chest compressor every 3 mins: Incorrect. Usually recommended every 2 mins to prevent rescuer fatigue, not 3 mins.

 

6. ETCO₂ <10 mmHg: Incorrect: Low ETCO₂ (<10 mmHg) indicates poor perfusion; target is ETCO₂ >10–20 mmHg during CPR.

 

8. Breaths 20–30/min: Incorrect:  Excessive ventilation; recommended rate is 10 breaths/min in adults with advanced airway.

questions.text:
Which of the following is statements about ICD-11 are true:

  1. It includes a new chapter on traditional medicine
  2. Gender incongruence and sexual dysfunctions are now listed as part of mental health disorders
  3. It has come into full effect from January 2022
  4. Chapter 6 is Mental, behavioural or neurodevelopmental disorders

Identify the correct statements:

  1. Grade 2 disability per 10 lac population is the most important leprosy awareness indicator
  2. VVM shows cumulative exposure of the vaccine to the heat and assess vaccine potency
  3. As per the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), HIV-TB prevalence of district >15% is a high-priority district
  4. The external validity of a screening test is related to generalizability
All of the following can be given by intra-tracheal route except:

Identify the correct statements about muscle relaxants:

  1. Gallamine and pancuronium have vagolytic activity

  2. Shortest acting approved NDMR is Gantacurium

  3. MR that may cause hypotension and flushing after injection: Tubocurarine

  4. Rocuronium and vecuronium can be reversed by use of Suggamadex
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Gallamine and pancuronium have vagolytic activity: True. Both can increase heart rate by blocking vagal tone.

 

Statement 3. MR that may cause hypotension and flushing after injection: Tubocurarine:  True. Tubocurarine causes histamine release, leading to hypotension and flushing.

 

Statement 4. Rocuronium and vecuronium can be reversed by use of Sugammadex: True. Sugammadex encapsulates aminosteroid NDMRs like rocuronium and vecuronium for rapid reversal.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Shortest acting approved NDMR is Gantacurium:  False. Gantacurium is ultra-short acting but not yet widely approved globally; atracurium or mivacurium are conventionally considered shortest-acting approved NDMRs.

questions.text: Topical steroids are not effective in which of the following:

Identify the correct statements:

  1. Lowest MAC=Highest potency

  2. Min MAC-N2o, Max MAC-Methoxyflurane

  3. Blood gas partition coefficient (BGC)=Lipid solubility-Speed of induction

  4. Lowest BGC-Xenon, Highest BGC-Methoxyflurane
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

Statement 1. Lowest MAC = Highest potency: True. MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration) is inversely related to potency; the lower the MAC, the more potent the anesthetic.

 

Statement 4. Lowest BGC – Xenon, Highest BGC – Methoxyflurane: True. Xenon has very low blood solubility → rapid induction and recovery, Methoxyflurane has high BGC → slow induction/recovery. 

 

  • Blood-Gas Partition Coefficient (BGC) is the ratio of anesthetic concentration in blood to that in alveolar gas at equilibrium
  • Low BGC = anesthetic is less soluble in blood, equilibrates quickly → fast onset and offset
  • High BGC = anesthetic is more soluble in blood, equilibrates slowly → slow onset and offset

 

Incorrect Options:

 

  • 2. Min MAC – N₂O, Max MAC – Methoxyflurane: False. Methoxyflurane has low MAC (high potency), while N₂O has high MAC (low potency). This statement is reversed.
  • 3. Blood-gas partition coefficient (BGC) = Lipid solubility – Speed of induction: False. BGC reflects solubility in blood, not directly lipid solubility; lower BGC = faster induction.

questions.text: A 42-year-old construction worker presents to a dermatology clinic with complaints of persistent, itchy, and red skin rashes on his hands and forearms. He reports that the symptoms worsen during and after work, especially when handling construction materials. On examination, there are erythematous, scaly plaques with vesicles and crusting on the dorsal surfaces of his hands and forearms. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this dermatitis?

Which of the following statements is true regarding sodalime?

 

  1. 100 g of sodalime can absorb 23 liters of CO2
  2. Amsorb is preferred for Sevoflurane and Desflurane over sodalime 
  3. The major constituent of sodalime is Ca (OH)2
  4. Water content of sodalime is 5%
  5. Can form a neurotoxic compound with Trilene
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Statement 1. 100 g of soda lime can absorb 23 liters of CO₂: True. this is an approximate value for fresh soda lime capacity.

 

Statement 2. Amsorb is preferred for Sevoflurane and Desflurane over soda lime: True. standard soda lime can react with sevoflurane/desflurane to produce toxic compounds (Compound A); Amsorb avoids this.

 

Statement 3. Major constituent of soda lime is Ca(OH)₂: True. calcium hydroxide is the main active component for CO₂ absorption.

 

Statement 5. Can form a neurotoxic compound with Trilene: True – soda lime can react with trichloroethylene (Trilene) producing potentially neurotoxic byproducts.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Water content of soda lime is 5%: False. actual water content is 13–20%, which is required for efficient CO₂ absorption.

questions.text: Following tube adds additional airway resistance. This is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diameter of the tube

 

The endotracheal tube shown adds airway resistance primarily due to its diameter. According to Poiseuille’s law, airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius (or diameter). Thus, a narrower diameter increases resistance much more than changes in length, circumference, or curvature.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of clean-cut injury which is not lacerated. He says that he received his last dose of tetanus vaccination about 10 years ago. What should be given next?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Single dose tetanus toxoid

questions.text:
Identify the correct pair of doses:

  1. Max dose of lignocaine without adrenaline-300mg

  2. Dantrolene sodium-2.5mg/kg

  3. Intralipid 20% IV-1.5 mL/kg

  4. Epinephrine in cardiac arrest-1mg 1:10000 iv
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Lignocaine (without adrenaline) – 300 mg: Correct. Maximum safe dose for an adult is 3–5 mg/kg without epinephrine; for a 70 kg adult, ~300 mg is appropriate.

 

Statement 2. Dantrolene sodium – 2.5 mg/kg: Correct. Initial dose for malignant hyperthermia treatment. May repeat until crisis resolves (max cumulative ~10 mg/kg).

 

Statement 3. Intralipid 20% IV – 1.5 mL/kg: Correct. Initial bolus for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). Followed by infusion if needed.

 

Statement 4. Epinephrine in cardiac arrest – 1 mg 1:10,000 IV: Correct. Standard adult dose every 3–5 min during CPR.
